最佳街头摄影设置（及其原因）一文首先出现在数码摄影学校上。它的作者是Olivier Duong 。

本文于 2023 年 11 月更新，由 Olivier Duong 和James Maher贡献。

选择最佳的街头摄影设置可能很棘手，但作为一名经验丰富的摄影师，我花了很多时间尝试不同的选择。多年来，我已经确定了什么有效，什么无效。

因此，在本文中，我将分享我最喜欢的街头摄影相机设置，包括：

  • 最佳拍照模式
  • 最佳光圈
  • 最佳快门速度
  • 最佳对焦设置
  • 最佳白平衡
  • （和更多！）

因此，如果您准备好像大师一样开始设置街拍，那么让我们直接开始，从概述开始：

最佳街头摄影设置：快速版

如果您急于出去拍摄，这里有一个最佳街道设置的快速列表：

  • 相机模式：光圈优先或手动
  • 光圈：f/8 及更窄
  • 快门速度：1/125s以上
  • ISO：200 及更高
  • 对焦方式：手动（区域对焦）
  • 白平衡：自动

当然，您的设置选择应取决于具体情况，正如我在本文其余部分中所解释的那样。

第一步

第一步总是涉及光。如果您不首先了解光线，您就无法弄清楚如何设置相机。光线有多强？今天是晴天还是阴天？是晚上吗？您是否在纽约，无论多么明亮，高楼大厦都会产生暗影，还是您所在的地区建筑物较小？

养成在第一次出去拍摄时看着光线的习惯，并且在继续拍摄时不要停止注意它！

街头摄影的最佳相机模式：光圈优先、快门优先或手动模式

相机模式决定了相机如何处理曝光；您可以自己设置曝光变量吗？或者你的相机会帮你做到这一点吗？

你有几个选择。您可以使用光圈优先模式，让您选择光圈和ISO ，同时相机自动选择快门速度。如果您要应对快速变化的光线条件，光圈优先会很好，但您需要监控快门速度以确保它不会降得太低。 （虽然在光圈优先模式下无法直接提高快门速度，但可以提高 ISO 或扩大光圈，效果相同。）

另一种选择是手动模式。它可以让您独立选择光圈、快门速度和 ISO。虽然这为您提供了额外的控制权，但您需要仔细注意相机的曝光条 - 当光线发生变化时，您需要相应调整设置。 （在数码单反相机上，这往往更具挑战性，但如果您使用无反光镜相机，则根据电子取景器中的曝光预览调整曝光相对容易。）

您还可以选择使用快门优先模式，该模式类似于光圈优先模式，只不过它允许您选择快门速度和 ISO，同时相机自动选择快门速度。

那么你如何选择呢？

老实说，如果您对这些模式中的任何一种感到舒适和熟练，那么您几乎可以在任何地方使用它们。但我发现根据情况切换模式是有益的。让我解释。

光圈优先

当光线中等至强时，我总是使用光圈优先。这是因为我希望能够打开相机并忘记设置。完成设置后，您就可以自由地享受自己并专注于内容。

现在，如果光线相当均匀，您就不必太担心，并且与更复杂的模式（即手动）相比，光圈优先不会产生太大的差异。但在阳光明媚的日子里，街道的阳光部分和阴暗部分往往会形成巨大的反差。每次从一个设置切换到另一个设置时更改设置是一件很痛苦的事情。

所以我要做的就是将相机设置为街道阴凉一侧的理想设置。这意味着我通常将相机设置为 f/8 或 f/11（有时为 f/5.6）和 ISO 800 左右（您可以根据阴暗面的实际暗度来调整这些值）。这将允许在阴影下至少 1/250 秒的快门速度。

代价是，当您将相机朝向太阳时，ISO 800 会比您在这种情况下通常使用的值稍高一些。但添加的颗粒效果很好，它可以让您在照明情况之间无缝地来回切换。你的快门速度会快到疯狂，比如 1/2500 秒。但这意味着至少你的拍摄对象会非常清晰！

快门优先

在阴暗的日子或一天中较暗的时间（例如清晨或傍晚），我会将相机设置为快门优先和 1/250 秒（有时在晚上为 1/160 秒或 1/125 秒）。这将保证运动被冻结，而如果您使用光圈优先，相机有时会低于该阈值以让足够的光线进入（而且很难时刻注意这一点！）。

然后我会根据光线的暗度将 ISO 设置为 1600 到 6400。这样做的原因是使光圈尽可能小以获得更大的景深，尽管在晚上您通常会以全开拍摄。

我不在晴天拍摄快门优先的原因是太多的光线照射到相机上。如果我在阳光下以 1/250 秒甚至 1/500 秒和 ISO 800 进行工作，我的光圈需要为 f/32 或 f/64 才能获得良好的曝光。我的镜头不能小于 f/16，因此这就产生了一个问题，迫使我在从阳光照射到阴影照射时必须更改设置。

手动模式

如果光线非常一致，或者如果您非常擅长使用手动模式，那么您当然可以使用此设置。凭借一致的照明，您可以轻松地通过手动选择设置并忘记它们。不过，如果光线不是很暗，我通常更喜欢光圈优先或快门优先。

我使用手动模式的时间经常是在晚上。那时天很黑，我需要选择尽可能最小的设置来冻结场景并使其清晰，通常是 1/125 秒和 f/2。有时我在室内拍摄街头照片时也会使用它，因为光线通常非常一致。例如，在地铁系统上，我通常会选择手动模式并以1/250s和f/2.8进行拍摄。一致的照明是手动模式的亮点！

归根结底，光圈优先、快门优先或手动模式都可以很好地工作。当然，当您进出阳光和阴影时，光圈优先会更方便，而当光线更有限时，快门优先会很好，如果您要处理更一致的光线，则手动模式会更好 - 但我最好的建议就是尝试所有这些并看看你的想法。

街头摄影的最佳光圈：f/8 及更窄

光圈会影响曝光和景深，因此仔细选择此设置非常重要。

较宽的光圈（例如，f/2.8）可让更多的光线进入，如果您想在阴凉处或夜间获得明亮的曝光，这非常有用，但较窄的光圈可提供更大的景深，因此您将在整个场景中获得更高的清晰度。

街拍应该选择哪个？

就我个人而言，我建议选择您能承受的最窄光圈。 f/8 光圈是一个很好的起点，但如果你可以缩小光圈，那就这么做吧。这里的目标基本上是最大化整个场景的清晰度区域。景深越大，对焦时的误差幅度就越大，因此即使您在拍摄对象的后面或前面对焦，图像仍然会变得清晰。合理？

如果您在弱光下工作，超窄光圈可能会导致严重的曝光不足，因此您必须保持灵活性。因此，当光线开始下降时，您可能需要扩大光圈以保持良好的曝光，这没关系。请注意调整将如何影响您的焦点区域。

请注意，您可以尝试使用大光圈（以及由此产生的浅景深）来创建美丽的艺术效果。这更常用于其他摄影类型，例如人像摄影，但如果您有兴趣捕捉独特的图像，请尽可能扩大光圈，看看能拍出什么效果！

街头摄影最佳快门速度：1/125秒或更快

如果您使用手动模式或快门优先模式，则需要自行选择快门速度。如果您使用光圈优先模式，则无法直接选择快门速度，但可以通过调整 ISO、调整光圈或调整曝光补偿来更改快门速度。

请记住，较快的快门速度可以防止相机抖动和运动模糊；因此，快门速度越快，拍摄的照片就越清晰。不幸的是，快速快门速度也会导致更少的光线进入，因此您必须在清晰度和曝光要求之间仔细取得平衡。

街头摄影应该选择哪种快门速度？

基本上保持在1/125s以上就可以了。街道上的事情通常发生得很快，如果速度低于 1/125 秒，就会面临相机抖动和运动模糊的风险。如果您要拍摄非常快的物体（例如骑自行车的人或汽车），我还鼓励您将快门速度提高到至少 1/250 秒。

如果你想更加确定你的镜头会变得清晰，你可以走得更高。问题是，你走得越高，你就越被迫提高 ISO，这会带来其他问题（正如我在下一节中讨论的）。

街头摄影的最佳 ISO：ISO 200 及更高

ISO 会影响图像亮度，因此当您想要使用窄光圈和/或更快的快门速度时，它会派上用场。不幸的是，虽然较高的 ISO 使场景变亮，但它们也会产生噪点- 但在我看来，许多街拍照片实际上在噪点下看起来不错，尤其是在黑白拍摄时。

这就是为什么我建议您在进行街头摄影时从 200、400 甚至 800 的 ISO 开始。只要您获得所需的快门速度和光圈，只需将其保留为这些值之一即可。然而，如果光线减弱，请根据需要增强光线。 （例如，在夜间拍摄时，您通常需要使用 1600 甚至 3200 的 ISO！）


街头摄影的最佳对焦设置：手动区域对焦

初学者街头摄影师经常使用他们奇特的自动对焦模式进行拍摄，但我推荐另一种选择：

手动区域对焦。根据我的经验，它比自动对焦更快，而且永远不会让您失望。

您会看到，许多最好的街头摄影师将镜头手动对焦在相机前面几英尺处，等到拍摄对象进入清晰度的预对焦区域，然后按下快门按钮。

查看此插图，其中包括几个可能的预对焦区域：

你看，通过提前手动对焦镜头，摄影师可以确保蓝色区域或红色区域始终处于对焦状态。这样，如果拍摄对象进入预对焦区域，摄影师就可以拍摄清晰的照片，而无需摆弄自动对焦设置。

因为事情是这样的：

即使您拥有世界上最快的自动对焦，也总会出现对焦延迟。另外，自动对焦可能会错过您的主要拍摄对象并击中另一个拍摄对象。

区域对焦可以消除这些问题，因为区域就像相机前面的力场。任何进入力场的东西都会成为焦点，这非常漂亮，对吧？

如何设置区域对焦

设置预对焦区域时，您需要考虑要拍摄的照片类型。

所以问问自己：我想要特写镜头的照片，还是想要远距离拍摄的人？这将决定完美的焦点。

假设您想在距离拍摄对象不到一米的地方拍摄几张照片。只要像这样放置你的镜头：

光圈为f/16，因此您应该将左侧的标记设置为0.7，然后查看右侧的“16”标记。你看到“1.2”时的情况了吗？这告诉您 0.7 到 1.2 米之间的所有物体都将成为焦点。

距焦点越远，景深越大。因此，将焦点放在一米处将使大量空间保持焦点。如果你想拍摄一米以外的人，你可以把最左边的“16”设置为“1”，然后检查最右边的“16”指示器来确定你最远的对焦区域。

如果您的镜头没有这些标记，没关系！这就是DOFMaster这样的工具派上用场的地方：

只需从下拉菜单中选择您的相机，然后输入镜头的焦距即可。选择光圈值，设置理想的拍摄距离（即焦点），然后点击“计算” 。

在右侧，您将看到聚焦区域（它将对应于近极限和远极限计算）。如果您喜欢对焦区域，请在拍摄对象距离处手动对焦并开始拍摄。如果您不喜欢对焦区域，请随意调整光圈值、拍摄距离，甚至焦距，直到获得满意的结果。

注意：当您选择焦距和光圈时，计算器还会为您提供这些设置的超焦距，即您可以聚焦以获得最大景深的点。将镜头设置为超焦距，从该距离的一半到无限远的所有物体都将保持在焦点上 - 如果您想保持尽可能多的画面清晰度，这是完美的选择。

事实上，我认识的大多数严肃的街头摄影师都将镜头设置为超焦距。只有当光线开始下降时，他们才开始扩大光圈并控制焦点；这样，他们可以保持曝光明亮并保持拍摄对象清晰。


街头摄影的最佳白平衡：自动

您可以使用白平衡预设来确定相机内的白平衡设置- 但根据我的经验，这主要是浪费时间。

首先，当您在现场工作时，很难获得完全正确的白平衡。

其次，摆弄白平衡可能会导致您错过原本可以拍摄的照片。

第三，只要你用RAW 格式拍摄——你绝对应该这么做！ – 几乎所有后处理程序中的白平衡都是可调的。

因此，只需将白平衡设置为“自动”，然后让相机自行决定。如果您喜欢结果，它将为您节省几秒钟的后期处理时间。如果您不喜欢，您可以随时在 Lightroom、Capture One 或 Adob​​e Camera Raw 中调整白平衡。

最佳街头摄影设置：最后的话

街头摄影是一开始就很难在技术上做好的实践之一。一切都发生得如此之快，手眼协调是如此重要，当然，在未经他们同意的情况下捕捉人们的坦率时刻会带来恐惧。虽然看起来你只需要等待合适的时机出现并获得幸运，但现实远非如此。

然而，讽刺的是，虽然技术方面一开始非常困难，但最终它们将成为第二天性，而真正困难的方面将是找到那些有趣和鼓舞人心的时刻。这些时刻并不经常发生，当它们发生时，你必须足够快才能看到并捕捉它们。所以，如果你没有打好基础，就很难进入下一步。

所以尝试一下我推荐的街头摄影设置。看看你有多喜欢它们。当然，仍然可以使用其他设置拍摄精彩的街头照片 - 因此，如果您决定走不同的路线，也没关系。

太阳耀斑可以为您的照片增添创意、美丽和戏剧感 - 如果您正在阅读本文，您可能会欣赏一些您最喜欢的风景照片、街拍或梦幻肖像中的耀斑效果。

但事情是这样的：您的镜片旨在防止这些所谓的“缺陷”。它们旨在为您提供最清晰、最自然的图像，并且零眩光。因此，当您进行太阳耀斑摄影时，您在技术上就违反了规则！

幸运的是，只要采用正确的方法，打破规则并捕捉华丽的耀斑效果就很容易，更不用说回报了。我在自己的摄影中一直这样做，在这篇文章中，我分享了很多建议来帮助您开始拍摄太阳耀斑。

让我们开始吧！

什么是太阳耀斑摄影？

那么太阳耀斑到底是什么？想象一下：你将镜头对准太阳，你得到的不是大的冲刷，而是明亮的光线条纹。或者它可能是一系列大小不同的漂浮球体，从光源处下降，就像天上的舞蹈一样。有时，它被定义为具有尖光束的恒星（有时称为“太阳星”）。

太阳耀斑可以有多种形式。无论从字面上还是形象上来说，它都可以成为您照片中的超级明星。或者它可以作为一个有趣的背景，提供足够的活力来让你的主要主题流行起来。

耀斑的美妙之处在于它的多功能性。您可以使用它来提升各种类型的摄影。肖像获得了空灵的品质，风景变得更加戏剧化，甚至你的街道或微距照片也变得更加有趣。

从本质上讲，太阳耀斑为您提供了广泛的创意选择。无论您是外出捕捉一览无余的风景还是关注花朵的细节，一阵阳光耀斑都可以提供额外的魅力。

拍摄太阳耀斑：给初学者的 17 个技巧

准备好自己创作一些令人惊叹的照片了吗？您可以在一天中的任何时间捕捉太阳耀斑，通过这些简单的技巧，您很快就能进行实验。

1.尝试各种光圈设置

您是否注意到，在某些照片中，太阳耀斑看起来柔和且分散，而在另一些照片中，它们看起来大胆而清晰？这与使用哪种光圈设置有很大关系。

如果您使用相当宽的光圈，例如 f/5.6，您会得到柔和的耀斑。但如果你使用小光圈，比如 f/22，你会得到更强、更清晰的耀斑。

在上面的分割图像中，f/5.6 镜头是看起来更柔和的光晕，而 f/22 镜头则更加清晰。耀斑点是由镜头内光圈叶片产生的。当叶片靠得更近时（如 f/22 等窄光圈），您会在光斑中获得更清晰的点。

使用不同的光圈将为您在编辑时提供多种外观可供选择。您还将了解您喜欢哪种类型的太阳耀斑，具体取决于您想要在照片中呈现的环境和感觉。

2.使用光圈优先模式

控制光圈的最简单方法（如上所述）是将相机置于光圈优先模式（佳能相机上用“AV”表示，尼康相机上用“A”表示）。这样，您就可以轻松调整光圈设置。

当您的相机设置为自动 ISO时，它会自动为您选择 ISO 和快门速度设置。

现在您将能够快速切换光圈并查看它对太阳耀斑的影响。

3.部分遮挡阳光

我最喜欢的技术之一是使用一个物体来部分遮挡太阳。想一想。一根栅栏、一座建筑物，甚至一根树枝都可以很好地达到这个目的。当你让太阳从这些物体后面探出头来时，你的图像又增加了一层复杂性。

效果可能是非凡的。当您围绕物体移动时，让太阳以不同程度显现出来，耀斑会发生移动和变化。有时它会包裹住你的物体，有时它会像光环一样爆发出来。这种技术可以为您的照片带来绝对迷人的深度感和艺术天赋。

但关键是实验。调整太阳相对于物体的位置会极大地改变图像的外观。小小的一瞥可以产生微妙的耀斑，而更多的阳光照射可能会产生强烈的光芒。两者都有影响力，具体取决于您想要实现的目标。

4. 四处走动并拍摄大量照片

拍摄太阳耀斑时，四处走动确实很有帮助——很多。如果您部分隐藏了太阳（如上一提示中所述），向右或向左轻微移动将导致耀斑发生巨大变化。您的照片可能被过多的光线淹没，或者您可能会完全错过耀斑。但移动也可以在正确的位置显示耀斑，以创造您所设想的外观。

拍很多照片很重要。您最终将了解应包含多少阳光与您想要的耀斑量。

太阳耀斑是不可预测的；这就是与他们合作的乐趣的一部分。

5. 拍摄有或没有眩光的照片

太阳耀斑几乎总是引人注目，但它们也可能是一把双刃剑。有时太阳耀斑会增强您的照片效果，有时也会分散您对拍摄对象的注意力。这就是为什么使用或不使用照明弹进行拍摄都是明智的。

例如，假设太阳悬停在画面边缘附近，产生柔和的漫射耀斑（如上图所示）。虽然它看起来很漂亮，但它也可能会分散您的主要拍摄对象的注意力。

所以你会怎么做？您在拍摄一张照片时将太阳完全遮挡，而在另一张照片中则允许它发挥作用。这样您回家后就可以自由选择效果最好的图像。

另一个技巧是当太阳靠近画面边缘时用手指遮挡太阳。稍后，您可以将此图像与包含光斑的图像合并。该技术允许您决定要在最终构图中保留多少耀斑。

我们的目标是始终拥有选择。太阳耀斑是不可预测的。有时你会喜欢它们带来的空灵品质；其他时候，你可能会发现他们拿走的比增加的多。

6.尝试使用一些过滤器

拍摄太阳耀斑时，滤镜会很有帮助。我建议考虑以下任一选项：

  • 偏光滤镜：旋转此滤镜时，您会得到不同的效果。它可以帮助增加颜色饱和度并减少反射。如果您有偏光镜，请尝试使用它，看看它如何影响耀斑。
  • 渐变中性密度滤光片：该滤光片顶部较暗，底部附近变浅。它可以防止在阳光下拍摄时部分图像看起来过曝。

我在右侧的照片中使用了渐变中性密度滤镜。它有助于控制光线，使颜色更加丰富。

7. 在一天中的不同时间拍摄

日出和日落时分，阳光以独特的角度射入。这会产生更温暖的金色光线，而在中午，则会产生更冷（蓝色）或更中性的光线。

在下图中，其中两张照片是在日落时分拍摄的，另外两张是在日出后几个小时拍摄的。你能猜出每张照片的拍摄时间吗？

我敢打赌你没看错——左边的照片是在日落时拍摄的。他们有一种更温暖的感觉，不是吗？而右边的图像给人一种更酷的感觉。

8. 用相机分割太阳

您可以通过构图使太阳不完全进入画面来获得更柔和、更分散的外观。尝试将太阳切成两半，或者只包括其底部的三分之一。

玩它。创建不同的效果，看看您喜欢哪种。

9.使用三脚架和遥控快门线

正如我之前提到的，较小的光圈设置（较高的 f 值）将为您带来更锐利、更清晰的耀斑。

但使用小光圈也意味着您的相机将需要更多时间来拍摄照片。图像拍摄时间越长，相机抖动导致模糊的可能性就越大。

如果您手持相机，这可能是一个问题。当您的相机安装在三脚架上时，相机抖动的可能性就会小得多。

使用三脚架将有助于让您的照片看起来清晰，让太阳耀斑看起来清晰。通过使用远程快门释放（或相机的自拍定时器），您可以进一步减少相机抖动。

10.让阳光照射在模特的背后

通过将阳光保持在模特的背后，您可以让耀斑的光线以有趣的方式洒落在模特周围。

根据一天中的不同时间，您可能需要躺下，并让您的模特也坐下或躺下。上面的照片是下午 3:00 左右拍摄的，当时我躺在地上。

太阳越高，为了将光晕放置在模特的头部或肩膀上，您需要的位置就越低。让你的模特坐下来会让你更容易。

当太阳在天空中较低时，定位对你们俩来说都变得更容易。

11. 将图像括起来

太阳耀斑摄影也面临着一系列挑战。前一分钟，你的拍摄对象曝光不足，下一分钟，你就眯着眼睛看着曝光过度的光球。这就是包围曝光可以发挥作用的地方。

包围曝光涉及以不同的曝光设置对同一场景进行多次拍摄。结果，您会得到一系列图像，每张图像都有不同的曝光，让您有更好的机会捕捉完美的镜头。

即使您无法获得成功曝光整个场景的单帧，您也可以随时在后处理中组合曝光。这个过程通常是在 Photoshop 等软件中完成的，它可以让你提取每张照片中最好的部分并将它们合并成一张。您可以在一张令人惊叹的照片中获得完美的耀斑、完美的天空和完美的主题。

但请记住，包围并不是一种万能的解决方案。根据您的场景，您需要调整拍摄数量以及曝光差异。这将使您能够覆盖全方位的光照条件！

简而言之，包围为您提供了选择和灵活性。当然，这是一个额外的步骤，但这可能意味着一张好的照片和一张非凡的照片之间的区别。

12.使用反光板

反射镜旨在将光线反射回拍摄对象上。反射器通常由织物（白色、银色或金色）制成，可以手持、悬挂在独立底座上或放置在地面上。

如果您的模型位于阴影中，使用反光板会很有帮助。它有助于提亮脸部，使照片看起来更讨人喜欢。

13.用手遮住太阳聚焦

拍摄太阳耀斑时可能很难对焦。光线太多，您的相机可能很难将焦点锁定在正确的位置。

发生这种情况时，请举起手遮住太阳，构图，然后半按快门释放按钮。相机对焦后，将手放下并完全按下快门。

您可能需要多次尝试，直到获得您想要的结果。

14.将太阳置于框架之外

要获得没有亮点的真正柔和的耀斑效果，请尝试将太阳移出画面。

我喜欢它如何增加柔和的光线（如上图所示），以及如何将眼睛吸引到光源上。

15.使用点测光

点测光可以很好地处理强光，因此如果您有选择，请选择这种测光模式。本文中除一张照片外的所有照片都是使用点测光拍摄的。

如果您的相机没有点测光，那么局部测光是下一个最佳选择。请注意，我使用自动对焦，并将对焦点设置为中心（因为对焦点是测光模式将处于活动状态的位置）。

16.做一些后处理

捕捉太阳耀斑只是旅程的一半。另一半发生在屏幕后面的编辑软件中。不要回避后期处理；当谈到让那些太阳耀斑真正脱颖而出时，它是您最好的朋友。

曝光度的简单调整可以使世界变得不同。也许耀斑太亮而洗掉了图像。把它调低一点可以带出你最初错过的细节。另一方面，增加曝光可以增强耀斑的效果。

白平衡也起着至关重要的作用。您可能更喜欢较冷或较暖的耀斑。只需滑动按钮，您就可以从夏日的金色变成冬日早晨的冰蓝色。尝试一下，看看什么最能补充你的主题。

除雾是另一个需要考虑的工具。有时太阳耀斑可能显得过于分散。添加去雾效果可以使光线更加清晰，耀斑更加引人注目。这个工具可以极大地改变照片的气氛。

不要忘记尝试颜色和对比度。添加一点对比度可以将耀斑与背景分开，使其更加明显。调整颜色可以改变光晕的气氛，让您可以自由创作，使图像独一无二。

17. 玩得开心！

最后一条提示可能是最重要的：

拍摄太阳耀斑时，尝试并享受乐趣。

不要害怕拍摄大量照片，尝试不同的光圈设置并四处走动。太阳耀斑是狂野且不可预测的。发挥创意并使用不同的物体来阻挡（或漫射）光线。您肯定会得到很多曝光过度和曝光不足的照片，但您也会得到很多华丽的结果。

拍摄太阳耀斑：最后的话

通过选择捕捉太阳耀斑，您将与众不同。您正在摆脱传统规则，敢于为您的图像添加额外的魔力。

更重要的是，您不必是专家才能开始。我们讨论的技术适合所有级别的摄影师！请记住，为了追求您独特的愿景，即使不打破规则，也应该改变规则。

所以拿起你的相机出发吧。无论您是徒步登山还是漫步熙熙攘攘的街道，阳光都已准备好与您的下一张摄影杰作合作。不要错过这个自然光彩的源泉。您的下一个镜头很可能是您迄今为止最好的一个。

作为一名摄影师，您可能经常发现自己在处理各种构图指南，试图为您的图像带来完美的和谐。但过于严格地遵守这些规则有时会让你的照片走上一条可预测的道路，剥夺它们独特的魅力。

这就是赔率规则发挥作用的地方，它是您摄影武器库中看似简单但功能强大的工具。这一切都是为了将​​你的主题排列为奇数，以制作出自然更赏心悦目的构图。与更多的静态指南不同，赔率规则提供了结构和有机流程的融合，使您的图像既美观又令人印象深刻。

因此，如果您想了解赔率规则是什么以及如何使用它来拍摄更好的照片，请继续阅读！

摄影中的赔率规则是什么？

赔率规则规定，只要有可能，组合应该具有奇数个对象，而不是偶数个对象。因此，一幅图像应该有三朵花而不是两朵，以及五个人而不是四个人。

为什么？赔率法则利用了大脑创造秩序的倾向。你看，当我们观看一组物体时，我们会无意识地想将它们成对分组。

但当我们面对照片中的三个、五个或七个物体时，我们就很难组织起来。对于奇数个物体，一个可能会成为主导。至少，观看者会更长时间地观看图像，在各个元素之间移动。

这就是摄影中胜算法则的力量：它创造出一种构图，让观看者的大脑更加努力地工作，看起来更长一些。

请注意，三个、五个或七个对象都可以很好地发挥作用。一旦超出了这些个位数，我们倾向于将所有对象视为一个组 - 即使它们是奇数。

根据赔率规则创作作品

某些类型的摄影赋予摄影师对构图的完全掌控权。

因此，您可以安排和构图场景以包含奇数个主题。

您还可以以令人满意的方式安排奇数个科目；例如，您可以包含强大的构图元素，例如线条和三角形。事实上，这些构图工具是挖掘观众大脑寻找线条和图案的另一种方式。

通常在静物构图中，我们有能力安排我们的主题，选择放置什么、在哪里以及放置多少对象。这使得应用赔率规则变得很容易，就像我在下面的照片中所做的那样：

其他科目的赔率规则

在大自然中，也许是拍摄风景，您通常无法选择在拍摄对象周围移动。相反，花时间探索你的场景 - 并找到利用摄影中的赔率规则的构图。

在户外拍摄时，看看如何用奇数个主要物体（无论是山峰、树木、岩石还是云）来创作构图。请注意，您仍然可以在后处理期间应用该规则；如果你有四个元素而不是三个，你总是可以克隆一个元素，就像我在下图中所做的那样：

规则的例外情况

进行一段时间的摄影，你会听到各种各样的“规则”—— 三分法、 倒数法、从左到右的规则，以及各种其他构图和相机操作规则。

当然，规则总有例外。有时，为了更好的构图而打破规则是件好事。那么什么时候应该打破赔率规则呢？

首先，拍摄人物时，不要总是墨守成规。如果你要拍摄一对情侣，那么使用第三个人就没有意义（事实上，这将为“赔率”规则赋予新的含义）。

当然，如果这对夫妇有一个孩子，那就太好了；三人小组将制定一个很好的赔率构成规则。然后，如果这对夫妇再要一个孩子，你就必须找到一种不同的方式来摆出他们的姿势，以适应赔率规则。

这是另一个打破赔率规则的时机：如果您要拍摄拉什莫尔山的照片。为了遵守赔率规则，你会排除谁？

因此，赔率法则应该像三分法则一样。当它可以增强你的构图时就使用它，但如果你的主题不允许使用它，也不要感到受到它的限制。

奇怪的一个

也许您在芝麻街上听到了这首歌，“其中之一不像其他事情。”这是该节目用来教孩子们观察思维的一场小游戏。

好吧，您可以在观众的心中玩类似的游戏。只需查找图像中某物奇怪，不同，不合适或不匹配的场景和构图即可。

这样的图像可以很强大。他们吸引观众的思想，引起人们对奇数对象的注意，并使您的观众看起来更长一点。

“奇怪的一个”图像的功能与照片中的对象数量有任何关系吗？可能会，也可能不会。也许它不符合赔率规则的标准定义。

尽管如此，这还是一种强大的技术，也是使吸引观众吸引的照片的好方法。

摄影的赔率规则：最后一句话

当有人告诉您您的照片很奇怪时，请以此为赞美！

认真地说，他们不太可能这么说，但是如果您可以找到接受摄影赔率规则的方法，那么您的书包将有另一个技巧。

不仅是正方形的臀部，而且很奇怪！

您如何看待赔率规则？您会在作品中尝试吗？您是否有任何赔率照片的规则？在下面的评论中分享您的想法和图像！

赔率是什么？

赔率规则指出，照片中的奇数对象（3,5,7等）将比观看者更具吸引力，而不是偶数对象。

最容易使用的赔率规则是哪种摄影？

可能仍然是生活摄影，您可以完全控制镜头中的物体数量以及它们的布置方式。

我可以在景观摄影中使用赔率吗？

是的，您经常可以！即使您无法在场景中移动对象，也可以小心地构图并构架图像以利用奇数的主题。
有时，您还可以在编辑中裁剪图像，或添加/删除对象以创建奇数的主题。

构图的“奇怪的一个”方法是什么？

一项好的技术可以是寻找破坏规范或“脱颖而出”的事物，因为它们与照片的其余部分不同。这样的物体将立即吸引观众的眼睛，并成为照片中的焦点。想想在黄色田地上的一朵红色花，一条汤匙的叉子，也许还有一只小鸡在十一个鸡蛋的纸箱中，您会明白的。

1. Fujifilm X100V（最好的街头摄影相机）

早在2010年，Fujifilm发布了原始X100，这是一种刻痕模型，具有开创性的功能，包括混合光学/电子取景器和APS-C传感器。它很快成为失控的。

X100V是这台相机的第五次迭代，多年来，Fujifilm稳步完善了其街头摄影功能。孔径，快门速度，ISO和曝光补偿设置各自具有自己的控制拨盘，因此它们可以简单地进行即时调整。混合取景器可让您使用OVF，EVF甚至老式的测距仪显示器拍摄，而翻转触摸屏则可以轻松从低角度组成。

街头摄影师的其他好处包括与APS-C传感器配对的23毫米固定镜头，这导致了35mm等效的视野，非常适合街头摄影。镜头锋利而明亮，最大孔径为f/2，因此您不必担心由于光线不良而缺少射击。内置的叶子快门几乎使摄影保持沉默，如果您重视自由裁量权，那就太好了。

X100V很小，但不太袋装，并且具有一套可自定义的按钮和拨号套件以适合您的样式。如果您想从头开始为街头射击游戏设计的无杂音摄像机，那么富士X100V是一个很棒的选择。我认为，这是当今街头摄影的最佳相机。

优点：

  • 恒星图像质量
  • 易于使用的控件
  • 混合光学/电子测距仪风格的取景器（此列表中所有相机中唯一的同类）
  • 精美的JPEG文件，带有各种各样的可用胶片模拟

缺点：

  • 自动对焦不如一些同行快
  • 昂贵，特别是对于休闲摄影师
  • 没有图像稳定

2. Ricoh GR III （最好的预算街头摄影相机）

多年来， Ricoh GR系列的相机一直是街头摄影师的最爱。这个古老的相机系列的第三次迭代延续了传统。它的尺寸很小，但很有用，它几乎提供了初学者或中级街头摄影师想要的一切。

与APS-C传感器配对的18mm镜头可导致28mm的视野；这比Fujifilm X100V（上图）宽一点，更像您在手机上可能会得到的。有些人喜欢更广泛的方法，如果是您，那么GR III将非常合适（尽管我必须承认我发现35mm的视野更令人愉悦和多功能）。图像质量非常出色，高ISO拍摄看起来很棒。许多摄影师发誓是正弦黑白JPEG的，因此，如果您想拍摄单色街头射击，这可能是一个不错的选择。

Ricoh GR III具有很多按钮，但没有像Fujifilm X100V（以及此列表中的其他摄像机）那样多的专用控件。快速更改设置并不那么容易，但是许多自定义功能都可以映射到特定的按钮以使事情变得更简单。最大f/2.8光圈不是线的顶部，但是相机可以通过内置图像稳定来补偿。只要您要拍摄仍然是主题，这会使弱光街道摄影更实用。一个非倾斜触摸屏使构图使镜头变得束缚，但是如果您希望通过将相机吸引到您的眼睛，那么缺乏专用取景器，这肯定是要考虑的事情。

优点：

  • 小尺寸使得轻松携带口袋或手提包
  • 比Fuji X100V和此列表中的其他选项更实惠得多
  • 卓越的图像质量
  • 内置图像稳定功能

缺点：

但是，尽管您可以以与Leica Q2相同的价格购买几个Fujifilm X100V和Ricoh Gr III，但您将在您根本不必与Leica考虑的过程中进行一些妥协和权衡。因此，如果金钱不是对象，并且您不介意从相机主体伸出的巨大镜头，那么Leica Q2是我的最佳建议。

9. Sony RX1R II

如果您正在寻找理想的街头摄影相机，但负担不起leica Q2，那么Sony RX1R II应该位于您的列表中。它在许多方面都与Leica相似，并且规格几乎超过了该列表顶部的每个相机，即使它的高度与德国制造的同类产品的高度不完全相同。

如何选择完美的街头摄影相机：5个关键特征

任何街头摄影体都将需要五个基本功能。虽然在单台相机中找到它们可能很艰难，但根据您当前的镜头阵容和首选系统，我建议您获得尽可能多的相机。

而且，如果您可以找到包含所有这些功能的相机，那么您就会知道这将是一个很棒的街头射击选项。

1.紧凑的身体

当您寻找街头摄影相机时，您要考虑的第一个方面是尺寸。

因为这是关于街头摄影的事情：人们注意到您的相机的人越少。

一旦人们开始看相机，他们就会变得紧张，您会感到紧张，摄影变得不舒服。

尽管不可避免地会看到您的相机，但越小，这种情况的发生就越少。

这就是为什么我建议您获得最紧凑的相机。或者，至少是提供较小外形的相机。

（紧凑型身体的另一个优点是它们很容易随身携带。您可以随身携带fujifilm X100V，无论您走到哪里，所以您永远不会错过任何射击！）

因此，通过寻找一个小的身体开始搜索，只有这样您才能考虑此列表中的其余功能。

顺便一提：

不仅应该很小的相机。您也需要小镜头。确保您有很多小镜头可供选择的最佳方法之一是使用微型四分之二摄像头（由松下和奥林匹斯提供）。

由于它们的传感器尺寸较小，这些系统具有异常紧凑的镜头。

2.高连续射击速度

如果您打算进行大量的街头摄影，那么您将需要一台快速拍摄的相机。

为什么？最好的街道照片往往涉及元素的融合。三个人完全与建筑物保持一致，一个人突然奇怪的表情，或者骑自行车的人在一个有趣的外墙前通过。

而且，您将错过这些时刻，除非您的相机可以快速连续地发射镜头。

我建议每秒至少连续五帧的持续拍摄速度更好。对我来说，8-10范围是理想的选择，这些天您可以在很多摄像机上找到。

老实说，对于大多数街头摄影目的而言，任何超过10 fps的东西都是过度的。您将快速浏览存储卡，最终得到大量不必要的照片。

您还希望获得带有不错的缓冲区的相机。如果您只能捕获15帧，则无用以10 fps射击。因此，我建议您寻找带有至少25个原始文件的缓冲区的相机（还有更多！）。

3.出色的自动对焦，具有强眼检测

正如我上面说的那样，街头摄影发生了很快，您经常会对即时来去去的时刻做出反应。

这就是为什么最好的街道摄影相机具有闪电般的自动对焦，理想情况下是面部/眼睛检测。

我说的是可以立即钉住聚焦的系统，并通过复杂的对象跟踪主题而不会失去焦点。

现在，有可能使用较少的AF型相机进行街头摄影。但是您会经常挣扎，尤其是在试图锁定突破性的镜头时。

当您从LCD或臀部拍摄时，您还需要适合AF。如果您的相机可以轻松地抓住焦点，即使您在不查看的情况下射击快门，您也会得到很多守护者！

4.无声拍摄模式

对于我的街头摄影来说，获得可以沉默的相机是一个真正的游戏规则改变者。最后，我可以在没有人意识到的情况下拍摄，这使我感到焦虑越来越大。

事实是，大多数街头摄影师一次或一次会感到焦虑，而大声的快门声音只是使这种焦虑更糟。

（如果您是街头摄影师，从不感到不舒服，请在评论中分享您的秘密！）

实际上，我几乎退出了街头摄影。只有我有一台相机才能进行真正的无声射击，我才能恢复并对自己的工作感觉更好。

这就是为什么我建议您获得具有某种无声拍摄模式的街头摄影相机的原因。理想情况下，它具有一个电子快门，可以使您完全沉默地拍摄（尽管任何无声拍摄模式总比没有好）。

但是，您需要小心：

使用无声快门时，可以限制一些摄像机。例如，我的索尼A6300在沉默时只能以每秒约3帧的速度射击，这可能非常令人沮丧。因此，我建议您寻找可以保持沉默和快速连续射击速度的相机。

这样，您就可以捕获动作爆发，而无需处理相机快门的chatter！

5.倾斜屏幕

此功能更可选，但是在许多情况下仍然有用。

您会看到，有时会想从臀部射击（即，保持相机低下并射击一些镜头）。

我这样做的时候在繁忙的街道上走过人们，因为我不想看着相机的景象。而且我也喜欢它创造的低角度外观！

当然，您可以盲目地执行此操作，最终会得到一些饲养员。

但是，如果您有一个倾斜的屏幕，则可以在步行时向下看相机，以确保焦点和构图完美！

请注意，您不需要完全铰接的屏幕，因为您不需要从超震动角度拍摄。倾斜90度的屏幕会很好。

而且，由于我们正在谈论屏幕，因此我会提到在这些情况下，触摸屏也很有用。如果您可以点击设置焦点，则可以在低头看LCD时快速选择一个主题，然后在距离近距离时开枪。

街头摄影是为了捕捉构成我们周围世界的坦率的日常时刻。几乎每个相机都可以捕获这些镜头，包括手机，口袋相机和带有大镜头的数码单反相机。

没有规则说您已经没有用于街头摄影的相机。而您唯一的限制是您为自己设定的局限性。但是，如果您正在寻找最适合街头摄影的相机，我希望此列表可以为您带来很多考虑！

街头摄影相机常见问题解答

我可以将手机用于街头摄影吗？

Mobile phones are great for street photography – as long as you have plenty of light. When the lights go down, photo quality decreases dramatically, especially if you're shooting moving subjects. (Night Mode on mobile phones almost always requires your subjects to be very still.)

What focal length is best for street photography?

This one is largely a matter of personal taste, but anything between 25mm and 35mm is generally ideal for street photography. Much wider than 25mm and people start to look a bit distorted. Much narrower than 35mm, and you'll have trouble fitting everything into the frame.

Can I use a DSLR for street photography?

While traditional DSLRs can certainly be used for street photography, I don't recommend them when there are so many excellent mirrorless options available. DSLRs are large and conspicuous, and Live View shooting often uses contrast-detection autofocus (which is highly unreliable for dynamic street photography scenarios).

Do I need weather sealing on my camera?

Unless you are shooting in extreme weather conditions, you probably don't need weather sealing. It's nice to have for peace of mind and I wouldn't recommend against it, but as long as you're careful not to let your camera get soaked with rain or covered in dust, you'll probably be fine.

Do I need to focus manually when shooting street photos?

Many street photographers enjoy shooting manually, which is very simple thanks to focus peaking on modern mirrorless cameras. However, autofocus works perfectly fine, and there is nothing wrong with using it for street photography.

What is Program mode on your camera, and when should you use it?

Program mode is one of those “odd one out” camera settings – something that most folks never try because they simply don't understand how it can help their photography.

Yet once you get the hang of it, Program mode is actually pretty darn useful. That's why, in this article, I aim to share everything you need to know about this mode, including:

  • What it actually is
  • 怎么运行的
  • How to use it for great results

So if you're ready to become a Program mode master, then let's get started.

What is Program mode?

The camera mode dial operates on something of a continuum. On one end, you have Manual mode , which gives you complete control over the three elements of exposure: shutter speed , aperture , and ISO . On the other end, you have Auto mode , which gives you almost no control over exposure.

As you can see in the diagram above, other modes exist in the middle of the spectrum. These modes – Shutter Priority, Aperture Priority , and Program mode – give you some degree of control, but your camera does significant work, as well. For instance, Aperture Priority lets you control the aperture and ISO while the camera determines the proper shutter speed for a good exposure.

So what about Program mode?它有什么作用？

Program mode exists somewhere between Aperture/Shutter Priority and Auto mode, and it works like this:

You set the ISO, while your camera sets the aperture and shutter speed.

(Remember: The ISO refers to the sensitivity of your camera sensor, the aperture refers to the lens diaphragm size, and the shutter speed refers to the length of time the shutter captures light.)

Program mode also gives you control over other camera features, such as exposure compensation, but I'll discuss that in a later section. For now, just remember that Program mode gives you ISO control, but leaves the aperture and shutter speed up to your camera.

(In fact, Program mode is sometimes referred to as “ISO Priority.”)

When is Program mode useful?

While Program mode isn't nearly as popular as Aperture Priority or Shutter Priority, it can make a big difference to your photography – you just have to know when to use it.

In essence, Program mode works best when you care about the ISO, but you don't care about the shutter speed and the aperture. This is either because you know that your camera will automatically give sufficient shutter speed and aperture values or because these settings won't affect the final result in a meaningful way.

So if you're shooting outdoors and you want to produce minimal noise in your photos, you might select Program mode, dial in a low ISO, and then let your camera do the rest.

Or if you're photographing under powerful artificial lights, you might tell your camera to keep the ISO low, then trust it to nail the remaining exposure variables.

底线：

If all you want to do is adjust the ISO, you're set. Put your camera in Program mode, change the ISO, and focus on composing and framing your shots rather than thinking about the aperture, shutter speed, and overall exposure.

But that's not Program mode's only use. You see, Program mode is also a great transition mode. If you're aiming to improve your photography skills but you're still stuck on Auto mode, you might try leveling up to Program mode; you can then use it as a stepping stone to Aperture Priority, Shutter Priority, and beyond.

How to shoot in Program mode

Back in the 35mm film days, you would often choose the film you used based on the shooting conditions you planned to work in.

ISO (or before that, ASA or DIN) was a function of the film. ASA speeds of common film types might be 25, 64, 125, 200, 400, and maybe up to 800. You could go a little higher with special processing. The rub was that, whatever film type you chose, you worked with the same ASA for the entire roll (be it 12, 24, or 36 exposures).

Working with Program mode can be a little like shooting film – in that the first thing you do is pick your ISO setting.

This could be ISO 100 for good outdoor light, ISO 200 or 400 for lower lighting conditions, and ISO 800 or higher for dim conditions (or perhaps for when you will be shooting action and need to use fast shutter speeds).

Some photographers call Program mode “ISO Priority,” because once you dial in the ISO, it will remain set, even as the shutter speed and aperture change. (Of course, the big difference from film is that you can change the ISO from shot to shot if you so choose).

So you start by setting your ISO.

Then, unless you have a special reason not to, I suggest you use the averaging metering modes : Evaluative on Canon, Matrix on Nikon. These will consider the entire image and calculate the exposure.

If your camera is set to Program mode, you will now see that it has selected both aperture and shutter speed settings. Depending on the available light, these will usually be toward the middle of the settings range – perhaps something like 1/125s and f/5.6. You may want to change these, and we'll get into that in a minute, but if not, you're good to go. Nail the focus and take the shot.

You can shoot all day like this, with your camera pretty much working as a point-and-shoot machine. As a beginner, rather than puzzle over what your settings should be for each shot, you can use Program mode to concentrate on more important things – chiefly composition – and let the camera figure out the exposure . Take away the clutch and the gearshift, and driving is so much easier, right?

Program mode: beyond the basics

At this point, you should be comfortable with the Program mode basics: You set the ISO, and your camera does the rest.

But if you dig a little deeper, you'll find more useful features to unlock. Many of these can help you get the shot you want, instead of the shot your camera thinks you want. In this way, Program mode is like the late-night infomercial version of Auto; it handles all the nitty-gritty complicated stuff for you, but ends with a “Wait, there's more!”

First, Program mode allows you to use exposure compensation to correct any exposure mistakes. By adjusting the exposure compensation in one direction, you can force your camera to take brighter images, and by adjusting it in the other direction, you'll get the reverse.

Say you take a photo of snow and it turns out too dark. With a little exposure compensation, you can bring back the snow's natural brightness (note that you can't do that in Auto mode).

And you can adjust plenty of other camera settings while in Program mode, including white balance , metering mode (full/center/spot), point of focus, and whether your camera should use its flash.

(Contrast this with Auto mode, and you should start to see the usefulness of the humble little “P” marker on your camera's mode dial.)

Of course, Program mode isn't always the way to go. Sometimes, you'll want to independently adjust your shutter speed or your aperture, in which case one of the Priority options, or even Manual mode, is the right choice.

But when ISO is all that matters, give Program mode a try.

Program Shift and some Program mode examples

You now know that Program mode allows you to set the ISO while your camera sets the aperture and shutter speed – but what if you want a narrower aperture and don't mind lengthening the shutter speed? Conversely, what if you want a faster shutter speed and don't mind widening the aperture?

That's where Program Shift comes into play. This option lets you adjust the aperture and the shutter speed together – so the exposure doesn't change, but the specific settings allowing you to achieve the exposure do.

The specifics for how to use Program Shift depend on your camera model, but I'd like to walk you through an example scenario where it can help you achieve top-notch results.

  1. It's an overcast day, so you set the ISO to 800.
  2. Your camera is in Program mode, and it suggests an exposure.
  3. You decide you want a deeper depth of field, so you use Program Shift to set the aperture to f/22.
  4. Your settings are now ISO 800, 1/20s, and f/22. (Note that you'll need to be on a tripod if you're using a 1/20s shutter speed.)
  5. You focus, then take the shot.

You take a look and decide it might be better to isolate the foreground leaves with a shallow depth of field. Still in Program mode, you use Program Shift to put the aperture at f/4. Your camera automatically adjusts the shutter speed to 1/640s to maintain proper exposure. You take another shot.

容易，是吗？ The ISO stayed locked in at 800, and as you adjusted the aperture, the shutter speed adjusted itself.

Suppose now you want to see the effect of shutter speed on a moving object. Still in Program mode, you leave the ISO at 800. To freeze the droplets of a fountain, you use Program Shift to set a 1/1600s shutter speed. You take the shot.

Now, what if you want to get a little motion blur on those drops? Use Program Shift to set a slower shutter speed of 1/50s. The aperture automatically adjusts.

(Exposure compensation is also an option should you need to make your images a little lighter or darker.)

Then make the leap

Program mode can help you get good exposures. And if you pay attention to the settings your camera chooses, you'll begin to understand the relationship between aperture, depth of field, shutter speed, and motion capture. Program mode can also give you a good jumping-off point to work with a mode such as Aperture Priority.

Say that after making a shot in Program mode, you see the camera chose f/11 as the aperture, and you like the amount of depth of field that resulted. You can then switch over to Aperture Priority mode (Av on Canon, A on Nikon), dial in an f/11 aperture, and start shooting. The camera will stay locked at f/11 while adjusting the shutter speed for various lighting conditions.

The same goes for shutter speed. If your Program mode shot shows a nice amount of motion blur at 1/5s and you want to make subsequent images with that amount of blur, switch to Shutter Priority mode (Tv on Canon, S on Nikon), dial in 1/5s, and shoot away.

The camera will stay locked on the shutter speed you chose and alter the aperture as needed.

Back to the safe spot

If you play around enough with your settings, you may eventually mess things up so that you create a bad exposure or become totally confused about why things are not working for you. That's when Program mode comes to the rescue.

Put the camera in Program mode, put the ISO to a setting appropriate for your lighting situation (ISO 200 might be a good starting point), and it'll be like hitting the reset button: you'll be back to letting the camera choose exposure settings.

Regardless of what mode I choose to shoot in, even Manual, I always put the dial back to Program mode before turning off the camera and putting it back in my bag. Then, if that once-in-a-lifetime shot presents itself and I must grab the camera, quickly power up, and shoot, I can be assured I will get a reasonably well-exposed shot.

I hope you will not take this article to mean you shouldn't learn to shoot in Aperture Priority mode or Manual mode, because it's true that a great number of professionals use these settings. But if you are new to photography and are confronted with more information than you can immediately absorb, working in Program mode might just be the helping hand you need.

Concentrate first on learning good composition. And make sure your images are well-focused, because blurry shots are impossible to fix in editing.

For now, let your camera help you with exposure until you begin to wrap your head around all there is to know. Even if you are a more experienced photographer, you might occasionally find that turning the mode dial and working in Program mode is the right choice for a given situation.

Program mode: final words

Program mode is a handy little option, even if it's often eclipsed by Manual, Aperture Priority, and Shutter Priority.

So the next time you don't want to give up all control over your camera but also don't want to do everything yourself, consider Program mode. You might ask yourself, “Do I need to adjust the aperture? And do I need to adjust the shutter speed?”

If the answer is “No,” then Program mode is probably your best option!

You can easily get lost in the chaos of branches, shadows, and foliage. Not to mention grappling with the challenge of different lighting conditions and appropriate settings that can vary dramatically depending on the situation.

That's where this guide comes in. What is forest photography?

Ever looked at the array of trees in a woodland area and seen an opportunity to capture an amazing shot? That's the essence of forest photography. It's a broad field that covers any photography centered around woodlands. Whether it's the deciduous forests of North America, the boreal forests of Siberia, or the jungles of the Amazon, they all fall under the scope of forest photography.

It's more than just capturing a stand of trees. Yes, you can create a landscape shot with dozens of trees leading into the distance, but you might also focus on the detailed texture of bark or the delicate flowers on the forest floor. Forest photography is a versatile niche. You aren't limited to one approach; there are plenty of options available for your creative exploration.

Typically, forest photography is seen as a subset of landscape photography. However, its expansive nature means it can venture into the domains of macro photography – close-ups of leaves, for example – and wildlife photography, capturing the dynamic movement of a deer among the tree trunks. So, if you're drawn to forest photography, there's no need to feel restricted. The forest is a vibrant, diverse canvas just waiting for your creativity.

What makes forest photography special?

Simply put, forests are amazing photographic subjects. They offer endless opportunities for photographers to play with geometry, contrasting the vertical lines of tree trunks with the horizontal planes of the forest floor.

Photographing forests, however, isn't just about the natural lines and shapes they provide. It's also about the challenge of creating order from the inherent messiness of woodlands. A forest scene can be complex – even chaotic. Organizing such a scene into a cohesive frame presents an exciting puzzle for any photographer.

Another draw of forest photography is its tranquility. Forests are peaceful spaces, serene and quiet. It's this tranquility you get to capture in your images – and the act of walking through the forest with your camera, immersed in the calm and silence, is an experience that's therapeutic in itself.

Plus, as anyone who has spent time in forests will tell you, they're much more than just an aggregation of trees; each forest is a collection of innumerable organisms and interactions. Sure, trees are an essential part of a forest, but the whole is much more than that.

Without microbes, earthworms, and plants, there would be no nutrient-rich soil for trees to grow in. Without insects, birds, and mammals, there would be no one to spread tree seeds.

In other words, without everything else, a collection of trees is not a forest, it's a plantation. That diversity and richness is part of what makes forests such a fantastic place for photography – there are so many subjects, and so many different elements to appreciate!

The best gear for forest photography

While you can capture great forest photos with any equipment, there are a few items that will help you get high-quality forest images consistently.

三脚架

A sturdy landscape photography tripod is essential for any woodland photography; forest environments tend to be dark, and without a sturdy support system for your camera, you'll be forced to widen your aperture (and sacrifice depth of field ) or drop your shutter speed until you can no longer get sharp shots.

A full-frame camera

Second, while your camera choice isn't critical – in fact, you can capture great forest shots with pretty much any model, including a smartphone – I do encourage you to use a DSLR or a mirrorless camera, ideally one with a decent megapixel count and a larger (preferably full-frame) sensor. More megapixels offer greater flexibility when printing or cropping, while a larger sensor will enhance your abilities to capture high dynamic range scenes in a single shot.

If you can't afford a full-frame camera, however, don't sweat it. Today's APS-C and MFT models produce outstanding images (and they're more compact, too, which is a major bonus).

A variety of lenses

Next, if you do go with an interchangeable lens mirrorless model or DSLR, you'll want to carry a few lenses. A wide-angle prime or zoom will help you capture scenic-style shots, while a telephoto lens (such as a 70-200mm ) is great for tighter forest photography (eg, foliage, aerials, forest patterns). I'd also suggest grabbing a macro lens or at least a close-focusing lens like a 50mm prime. That way, you can shoot all sorts of little details, including leaves on the ground, fungus on logs, and flowers sprouting on the forest floor.

过滤器

Forests are pretty dirty, so it can be helpful to mount a clear or UV filter on all your lenses. If you do go this route, be sure you purchase a high-quality model; there are a lot of cheap UV filters on the market that'll degrade optical quality. Alternatively, you can simply carry a cleaning kit and keep your lenses well-maintained (always use a microfiber cloth, not rags or towels of any type!).

Finally, a polarizing filter can come in handy, especially if you plan to shoot fall foliage. It'll remove glare on wet leaves, deepen fall colors, and reduce reflections in bodies of water. Keep in mind, however, that polarizers reduce the amount of light coming into your camera, so you'll definitely need that tripod!

The best forest photography settings

To take a fantastic forest photo, you need to master your camera settings. The best settings vary based on the type of image you want to capture, but you'll want to start by setting your camera to Manual mode , which will grant you complete control over the image exposure. Another reliable choice is Aperture Priority mode .

If you aim to capture a scene with deep depth of field, meaning an image that's sharp from the foreground to the background, a narrow aperture is the way to go. Often, a setting of f/8 or higher achieves this effect. Such a setting is effective because it allows the viewer to fully immerse themselves in the scene:

This is the approach that I generally like to use when photographing forests – I'll set my camera to Manual mode, then dial in a relatively narrow aperture. (My starting point is f/8.)

On the flip side, a wider aperture can create a shallow depth of field, where a single element is in sharp focus while the background blurs. This technique is excellent for highlighting specific subjects like a leaf or a tree:

In most cases, a narrow aperture will likely serve you better, but don't neglect the power of a well-composed wide-aperture shot! (I'll often shoot the same scene with a few different apertures just to see how the images turn out. While I generally prefer the shots with a deep depth of field, sometimes the background blur does reduce distractions in a pleasing way!)

Once you've selected your aperture, set your ISO to its base value, usually ISO 100, and pick a shutter speed based on exposure considerations. The idea is to ensure there's enough detail in the shadows and highlights of the scene.

But bear in mind: To achieve a deep depth of field with an ISO of 100, you'll often require a longer shutter speed. This means a tripod is essential to prevent blur in your images. Additionally, if the branches of the trees are swaying in the wind, the longer shutter speed might cause motion blur, whether you use a tripod or not. Whether this effect is desirable is a matter of personal preference. I tend to like it, myself – but if you'd rather avoid it, you can always increase your ISO and shutter speed simultaneously.

14 forest photography ideas and tips

Now that you know the forest photo basics, it's time to really delve into the tips, techniques, and ideas that'll elevate your shots, starting with:

1. Take proper safety precautions

Before you head off into the forest – especially if you plan to go on a multi-day trip – consider any potential dangers. It can be easy to get lost in forests, plus they're often dark and feature rough terrain. And if you're not careful, you might get hit by a storm or a flash flood.

Always tell someone where you plan to be walking, and make sure you carry a phone that'll maintain a signal throughout your entire trip. Be sure to bring food, water, a map (if available, a topographical map is always best), a compass, sunscreen, and bug spray.

I'd also encourage you to bring rain gear for you and your camera. A waterproof covering will keep your camera safe, and unless your backpack is waterproof, I'd recommend carrying a cover for it, too. And bring a dry towel or rag to remove moisture, dirt, or rain from any exposed gear.

2. Go out when the light is right

Forest photography, unlike most types of landscape photography , can be done at any time of day – even in bright, direct sunlight.

You see, the forest canopy will filter out some of the harsh light, creating a more subdued lighting situation, one that you'd normally expect to find after just sunrise and before sunset.

So don't be afraid to go out on sunny days (though midday clouds can be even better!). If you do find that the light is too strong, you can always try shooting in black and white . Look for interesting shadows, powerful patterns, and high-contrast edges.

That said, forests are pretty magical around sunrise and sunset, so I'd urge you to head out during the early hours of the morning or late in the evening. If the forest is near water, you may get some ground fog, which can add lots of mood to your photos.

Note that forest photography during the golden hour tends to feature lovely warm light that gives trees a sort of fairy-forest look – while forest photography during the blue hour tends to feature soft, cool light that gives a more ethereal vibe.

3. Try to include a nice foreground subject

A truly compelling forest photo does more than just capture the scene. It invites the viewer on a journey, guiding their eyes from the foreground to the background. This is where your composition skills come into play. What better way to create this sense of movement and depth than by incorporating an engaging foreground subject?

You could find a cluster of wildflowers, an interesting rock formation, or a set of gnarled roots. The idea is to have an object that grabs the viewer's attention and then, through clever composition, leads them into the wider forest scene. Sometimes, something as simple as a fallen leaf can be a wonderful foreground element that complements the expansive woodland backdrop.

Getting low and close to your foreground element can emphasize its importance. But if you use this approach, be cautious – you'll need to set your aperture and point of focus carefully to ensure both the foreground and the background are sharp. Even the smallest shift in focus can cause blurring in one area or another. It's a delicate balancing act, but when you get it right, the results can be stunning.

Also, I know from experience that it's not always possible to capture a sharp foreground subject and a sharp background scene in the same frame, even with an ultra-narrow aperture. In such cases, I like to focus stack , where I take multiple photos of the same scene with different focus points, then blend them together in Photoshop. (It sounds tricky, but it's genuinely not; as long as you use a tripod and your scene doesn't feature moving subjects, Photoshop generates solid results without a whole lot of effort.)

4. Don't forget to shoot in portrait orientation

Most landscape shooters create horizontal compositions out of habit, but when it comes to forest photography, this is a mistake!

Yes, you can capture stunning horizontal forest images, but I'd also encourage you to try shooting vertical photos.

The vertical format will allow you to capture more of the (tree) scene, and it'll also give your images a sense of height. Make sure you pay careful attention to the edges of the frame – you don't want to cut off any key elements! – and keep the horizon level. While you can always correct crookedness in post-processing, you'll lose pixels along the way, which is never a good thing!

Also, if you're not sure whether a scene will look best in the vertical or horizontal format, just take both shots. Once you're in the editing room, you can evaluate the compositions and see which works best.

5. Color contrast is key

One drawback to shooting in a forest environment is the lack of color contrast. Unless it's autumn, the majority of your environment will most likely be composed of green leaves and/or brown tree trunks, which can lead to bland, boring photos.

So you should do whatever you can to add pops of color.

For instance, patches of brightly colored flowers can offer an eye-catching touch. Same with colorful insects!

And even if you can't find a colorful subject in the area, you can always try to use the light. By including golden-hour sun or flare in the frame, you'll get beautiful oranges and reds (which will give your shot a more vibrant look).

6. Try black and white

Sometimes, when you're shooting in a forest, nothing seems right. The light doesn't hit the way you want, the colors feel off, or you just don't get a sense of drama from your subjects.

This is a common issue among forest photographers; it's due to the general consistency of color from scene to scene, and how too many greens and browns make it hard to highlight a subject.

But if you shoot in black and white, you can ignore the color monotony, and you can instead concentrate on the light and tones and composition. Look for interesting atmospheric effects such as fog, and do what you can to organize forest chaos into orderly structures.

Note that you can create black-and-white images in two ways:

You can switch your camera to its black-and-white mode, or you can work in color and convert to black and white during post-processing.

Either is fine, but the two methods do have their pros and cons. If you work in black and white, you'll be able to review the monochrome image on your LCD (and if you shoot mirrorless, you can preview the scene through the EVF).

On the other hand, if you work in color, you have the choice of converting to black and white or keeping the original shot. (This is an option afforded to all RAW photographers , whether shooting in color or black and white – but if you shoot JPEGs, you won't be able to convert a black and white image to a color file.)

7. Seek out intimate shots

While capturing the grandeur of the forest is a wonderful experience, sometimes it's the smaller, intimate details that create the most meaningful images. These images showcase the hidden beauty of the woodland, the little elements that you might miss when you're focusing on the wider scene.

Switch your mindset from the expansive to the minute. Instead of looking up at the towering trees, look down and notice the patterns in the fallen leaves or the way the moss blankets a fallen log. If you have a macro lens, you can get especially up close and personal with your subjects so you can create images that offer a different, more intimate perspective.

A few drops of water on a leaf, the texture of tree bark, a small stream winding its way through the undergrowth, or even a lone mushroom sprouting from the forest floor – these can all be extraordinary subjects. Each element adds a different layer of appreciation of the forest and can bring you beyond the traditional forest photo into a realm of unique, detailed woodland imagery.

8. Remember the big picture

On the flip side, don't just focus on the trees and the details! When heading out for a forest photography session, make sure you capture a few wide-angle shots of the forest itself. These give an overview of the kind of forest it is, what kinds of creatures live there, what season it is, what state the forest is in, and so on.

These shots might seem a little obvious, but obvious shots aren't always boring!尝试找到一个能够讲述故事、具有独特氛围或情绪、或者能够给观众带来惊喜的角度。 Don't just point and shoot, but think, plan, and frame your woodland photo.

9. Photograph in every season and all types of weather

Forests are not static; they are living entities that transform dramatically with the changing seasons and weather conditions. And as a forest photographer, you should strive to embrace this variability, rather than avoid it.

Summer, with its lush green canopy, offers opportunities for photos bursting with life and vitality. In autumn, forests turn into a riot of color, with the reds, yellows, and oranges creating a stunning backdrop for your images.

But don't forget about spring, when new leaves bud and flowers carpet the forest floor. And winter, despite its challenges, can produce some of the most magical forest images. Snow-covered branches and frost-covered leaves can create enchanting scenes straight out of a fairytale.

Forests also provide striking scenes in varying weather conditions. Fog and rain can transform the familiar into the mysterious and the mystical. Photographing forests in near-whiteout conditions or on misty mornings can give your images an abstract or impressionistic feel, emphasizing the shapes and forms of the forest rather than the individual trees.

Of course, if you do shoot in these conditions, remember to protect your camera gear. Working with a rain cover is a great starting point, and whenever possible, change your batteries and memory cards in a dry, covered location.

(I love photographing forests during winter, especially right after a snowfall! The trees tend to be more heavily coated with snow, which – at least for me! – makes for better shots. Of course, if you do head out for a winter forest photoshoot, make sure you dress warmly and as mentioned above, do your best to protect your gear from the elements. I always carry a rain cover that I put over my camera if the snow starts falling, and I'm very careful about taking my cold camera into the warm car or house afterward – I like to keep my equipment in an opened bag for a few hours so it can acclimate to the temperature change.)

With a bit of preparation, you'll be ready to capture the forest's many moods – in any weather and every season.

10. Capture that classic “path through a forest” photo

Photographs of paths winding through forests have a mesmerizing charm, so it's no surprise they are a staple in forest photography.

Sure, they're popular, and yes, you might even say they've become a bit of a cliché. But remember, clichés are clichés for a reason.他们工作。 They appeal to something universal within us. A path through the forest isn't just a path. It's a metaphor for the journey of life, full of twists, turns, and surprising discoveries.

What makes a forest path so visually fascinating is its ability to act as a leading line in your composition, drawing the viewer's eye into and around the image. It adds depth and dimension, creating a structural pathway that naturally invites exploration.

So whenever you head into a new forest, spend some time photographing its paths. How you capture it is completely up to you. Yes, you can go for the classic shot: path in the middle, trees rising majestically on either side. It's a time-tested composition that never fails to impress. But let me urge you to think outside the box a bit. Play around with the composition. Frame the path off-center, try shooting from an unexpected angle. There's a whole world of creative possibilities waiting for you.

Pro tip: An overcast or dreary day can add an extra layer of moodiness, creating a more compelling visual narrative.

11. Photograph on the forest edges

Being deep inside a forest can feel magical – like you're immersed in another world. It's an exhilarating feeling. But sometimes, especially when trees are densely packed, it can limit your options for telephoto shots from a distance.

Here's where the forest's edge, or even a forest clearing, can come in handy. It's an area with plenty of open space that allows you to step back, mount a telephoto lens, and capture a different perspective.

Look for patterns formed by tree trunks and branches. Forget about seeing them as trunks and branches; start seeing them as lines and shapes. Try to create an abstract composition that leads the viewer's eye around the frame.

Sure, it might take some persistence and a lot of shots. But believe me, when you manage to capture that stunning image, it'll all be worth it. You might even end up with a photo worth framing and hanging on your living room wall!

12. Try some experimental shots

If you're not especially interested in forest photography and you were dragged out to a smelly forest full of biting insects and other nuisances against your will, don't despair. There's something to do, even for you!

Forests offer great opportunities for trying out different kinds of experimental photography. The low light conditions and diverse scenery work well for techniques that require long shutter speeds, such as intentional camera movement and light painting.试一试！

13. Post-process to enhance your forest photos

Post-processing is an essential part of forest photography; it's how you refine your photos and really make them pop.

I'd recommend you start your editing workflow by making basic corrections (exposure, white balance , cropping, etc.). Then go into the more advanced adjustments, such as targeted contrast and color grading .

Lighting tends to be more dramatic in the forest and can result in gorgeous rays hitting the forest floor – so draw attention to these by adding contrast to the sunlit areas. You might also try applying a bit of Vibrance to the overall image and playing around with the hue and saturation of individual colors to bring out a natural feel in the shot.

For my own images, I like to decrease the Lightroom Clarity slider , which gives a dreamy or magical feel. I then apply local adjustments to important areas of the photos, such as the main subject. During the latter editing phase, I'll often use a Brush to boost the Clarity and the sharpness for a little extra crispness.

But there's no single best workflow for forest photography. It's really all about experimenting and finding what works for you!

14. Leave the forest as you found it

The forest is beautiful, mysterious, and amazing. It's worth preserving for the next generation, so please, please, please do whatever you can to keep it clean.

Whenever you're out shooting, make sure you clean up all your trash, including plastic bags and water bottles. And if you see trash left by others, consider cleaning that up, too.

Also, respect the environment. Don't get too close to wildlife, and don't disturb sensitive plants or trees (by trampling over them, climbing them, etc.).

Little things like that may seem trivial, but if we all take care of the environment, we can have a positive effect on our natural world, and we can keep it in good health for generations to come.

Plus, there's an element of self-interest to consider: The cleaner the forest, the better your photos will look!

Forest photography: final words

We've journeyed together through the enchanting world of forest photography, sharing crucial tips and effective strategies to help you capture the beauty of the woods. By now, you've gained a solid understanding of the gear, settings, and techniques needed to turn your forest excursions into stunning photo ops.

Sure, translating the mesmerizing charm of forests into photographs might still feel challenging. Remember though, every professional photographer started where you are now. With the knowledge you've gained from this guide, you're already steps ahead, ready to tackle those intricate details and dynamic lighting conditions that make forest photography such a fascinating pursuit.

Forest photography FAQ

What focal length should I use to photograph forests?

Variety is your friend! Both wide-angle lenses and telephoto lenses can work magic in a forest setting. And don't forget a macro lens for those intimate detail shots.

What shutter speed is best for forest photography?

As a rule of thumb, I recommend a longer shutter speed, often below 1/100s. This compensates for the limited lighting you often find within forests.

What's the best time of day to take pictures in the forest?

我非常喜欢清晨——人少，偶尔还会有美丽的雾气。 But you can also shoot in the afternoon and even at midday (especially if it's cloudy!).

Do I need a tripod for woodland photography?

Yes, a tripod is very useful. Given the lower light conditions of most forests, a tripod will prevent camera shake and allow you to use optimal settings for the shot.

Capturing stunning portrait photos at midday, when the sun is bright and high overhead, can be very, very difficult.

(Most serious portrait photographers try to avoid midday lighting at all costs, and for good reason: the harsh light beats down on subjects and creates wildly unflattering shadows.)

However, you won't always get to choose when and where your portrait sessions take place – so it pays to know a few tips and tricks for managing that harsh midday sun.

In this article, I share my best advice for doing midday portrait photography. And while midday light is rarely ideal, if you use the tips and techniques I share below, your images will be much improved.

1. Backlight your subjects

Backlighting is great for sunset silhouette photography …

…but did you know that you can also use backlight in the late morning and early afternoon? As long as the sun is slightly angled, then backlighting is possible, and it's a great way to keep your subjects looking good in harsh, bright light.

You see, by backlighting your subjects, you keep direct sun off their faces, and you also avoid those weird shadows that occur under the eyebrows, nose, and chin.

Backlighting will also help keep your subjects from squinting, which is a big problem during midday sessions.

So simply find the sun, then position your subjects so they're facing away from the light. You may get lens flare , but I'm actually a fan of the look:

One word of warning:

When you're working with backlighting, your choice of background may be limited. But make sure you put in extra effort to find a complementary, non-distracting backdrop; otherwise, while your subjects may look great, the background will draw the viewer's eye.

2. Try a black-and-white conversion

Black-and-white photography seems almost nostalgic in the age of vibrant digital images – but in harsh lighting, converting your color portraits to monochrome can be a game-changer.

为什么？ It turns the unpleasant aspects of harsh light into something visually engaging.

The first thing to know is that a black-and-white conversion can simplify an image. It reduces visual distractions and makes the portrait more about shapes, tones, and contrasts.你猜怎么着？ Here, harsh lighting, often a hindrance, suddenly becomes an asset. It contributes to the dramatic contrast that black-and-white images thrive on.

But how do you go about it? If you're shooting with a digital camera that has an electronic viewfinder, switch to Monochrome mode in advance. This lets you see the world in black and white through your viewfinder, so it's a great way to anticipate what your final image will look like.

No electronic viewfinder?没问题。 Try to visualize the scene in black and white as you shoot. Imagine how the bright sunlight and deep shadows will translate into whites and blacks. Then convert the image in post-processing using software like Adobe Lightroom or Photoshop.

And remember, just because you're working in monochrome doesn't mean you can't experiment. Play around with different settings in your editing software. Tweak the contrasts, adjust the brightness, and even add some film grain for a vintage feel. Sure, it might not work for every shot. But you might stumble upon a few unexpected masterpieces along the way!

3. Use reflectors

The biggest issue with midday portrait photography is the shadows , which fall under the eyes, nose, and chin and can keep subjects from looking their best.

Fortunately, we have an easy tool to dial back unflattering shadow areas: reflectors .

Reflectors are flat expanses of material – generally white, silver, or gold – that reflect light back onto the subject. They're extremely cheap, though if you'd prefer not to spend extra money, you can always make a reflector or two with a bit of poster board.

During your photoshoot, angle the reflector so sunlight fills in the shadows; that way, you'll get a much more flattering image.

You can get similar results using natural reflectors, such as a white wall or even white sand:

In fact, natural reflectors include big parking lots, sidewalks, windows, silver or white cars, buildings with silver or reflective paneling, light-colored cement walls/floors, and so much more!

One note: If you use a shiny reflector, make sure not to aim the reflected light directly into your subject's eyes. It can be really bright, almost as strong as direct sunlight , and you don't want to cause discomfort!

And don't place your reflector on the ground in front of your client. This will cause the light to bounce upward and give you odd, unflattering shadows on the face. Instead, use a stand, or ask a friend to hold the reflector around torso height.

4. Use a scrim to diffuse the light

A scrim is a piece of translucent fabric that diffuses the light, and by positioning a scrim between the light source and your subject, you can create a soft, even effect that looks amazing in portraits.

Note that you can purchase scrims online; in fact, most 5-in-1 reflectors come with a translucent side, which can be used as a scrim.

(You can also make your own scrim using translucent fabric and a hula hoop.)

During your photoshoot, simply hold the scrim over your client's face or body. It'll diffuse the bright sun, and you'll get a very nice effect.

Pay attention to the background, however. If the background is brighter than your subjects, it'll turn out overexposed. Try to match the light on the background to the light on your client !

5. Slightly underexpose your subject

Harsh sunlight tends to wash out the scene, which makes for a colorless, boring, unpleasant background:

Fortunately, a bit of underexposure can go a long way toward maintaining beautiful background colors and tones. And underexposure will ensure you retain details that'll otherwise get clipped.

Of course, underexposure will also result in too-dark subjects; that's why, after a portrait session, you should tweak the exposure in post-processing. Bring up the shadows in your editing program of choice, and you'll get a beautiful result:

6. Try going wide

A common belief in portrait photography circles is that focal lengths of 50mm or greater are the best for capturing faces. True, these lenses can produce flattering facial features and provide a pleasing background blur. But a more expansive view can also work, especially in harsh lighting situations.

Consider using a wider lens and taking a step back – literally. What does this accomplish? For starters, it makes your subject a smaller element within the composition. The beauty of this is that it diminishes the emphasis on any unflattering shadows that harsh light can cast on facial features. Instead, the viewer's attention is directed toward how your subject fits within the surrounding environment.

A wider frame can also help mitigate the tension between bright spots and dark shadows. It essentially acts as a buffer, creating a more harmonious blend between the subject and their background. Think of a beach portrait where the subject becomes part of the larger seascape or a street portrait that incorporates elements of urban architecture. When shot from a distance, highlights and shadows that were once distracting suddenly become part of the overall scene.

The concept of “going wide” isn't new, but it's vastly underutilized in scenarios where photographers are dealing with challenging lighting. By opting for a wider lens and making your subject a part of a larger scene, you might find that the so-called “problems” of harsh light can be transformed into visual assets!

7. Use flash to brighten up your subjects

Many beginners are intimidated by flash photography , but it's not that hard to do, and it's a great way to improve your midday portrait photos.

For one, an extra pop of light can handily dispel unwanted shadows. Plus, a bit of flash will help you correctly expose for a bright background and get great detail on your main subject:

Since you'll be competing with the bright midday sun, point your flash directly at your clients to make sure the light reaches them. And set your flash to 1/8th power or more. That way, you can light your clients without causing an imbalance with the background.

Pro tip: Once you get good at using basic fill flash , e xperiment with your flash's high-speed sync mode . The light will be more directional and your background will be darker , making for unique, fashion-style portraits .

8. Work with a high-powered strobe

As I explained in the previous section, a well-placed burst of light can add a nice fill to your subject's face. Now, let's take it a step further. Imagine not just supplementing the existing light but actually overpowering it.

That's where a high-powered strobe comes in. These aren't your everyday camera flashes. We're talking about specialized units that bring incredible intensity to the table. Granted, strobes aren't exactly budget-friendly, and they can be quite bulky. But the level of control they offer is unparalleled.

Of course, a powerful strobe can cause the exact type of harsh-light issues that you're trying to prevent if not managed carefully.解决方案？ Use a softbox. This attachment diffuses the light, avoiding that harsh, sun-like quality that can ruin your shots. Once everything is set, fire away and watch how the background falls into complete darkness, isolating your subject in a pool of perfectly controlled light.

9. Use your camera's “Shade” white balance preset

White balance is all about creating images with accurate colors, so you may be wondering:

Why would I ever want to shoot midday portraits while using the Shade white balance option? After all, isn't the Shade preset meant to shoot in, well, shade ?

And you're right:

The Shade white balance preset is designed to work in shady conditions. But in my experience, Shade actually helps keep skin tones looking even .

This is very important, especially when shooting at midday; the bright sun can cause all sorts of skin tone issues, and if you're not careful, you may run into serious problems.

Note that you can always tweak the white balance when editing in a program like Lightroom or Photoshop (assuming that you're shooting in RAW ). I'd recommend using the Shade preset while out in the field. Then check the results when you're back in front of the computer. That way, you can be sure you get the best files!

10. Experiment with interesting shadows

We often perceive shadows as unwanted elements in portrait photography. Harsh light, especially around noon, intensifies this problem. But what if we shift our perspective and see these intense shadows as opportunities?

Take a walk in your location and look for interesting objects that could cast compelling shadows. Think leaves, building edges, and trellises. These ordinary objects can be your secret weapon in combating harsh light. They cast unique shadows that can dramatically alter the mood and composition of your portraits.

Placement is crucial. Once you find the perfect object, position your subject in the path of the shadow. Then experiment with different looks, so that the shadow falls across their face, arms, or even just their legs. The idea is to introduce a different element that breaks the monotony of the harsh light while also working within the overall composition.

Remember that your approach can be quite experimental here! Try different angles, adjust your subject's position, and vary your own viewpoint. Each change can result in a new and interesting composition. The beauty is in the unpredictability, as you never know how the shadow will work with your subject until you see it.

Take several shots with these shifting shadow placements. You'll likely be surprised at the unique images you capture. They may not fit the standard mold of portrait photography, but that's not necessarily a bad thing!

11. Embrace the high-contrast look

Portraits taken in bright sunlight look unpleasantly high contrast .

But what if, instead of trying to eliminate the high-contrast lighting, you embraced it?

For instance, you might position your subjects directly under shadows for a cool effect. Or you might front light your subjects to highlight interesting details. Or you might use harsh sidelight for an intense, in-your-face result.

Here are just a few examples of high-contrast midday portraits:

You can also use hats, palm leaves, water, and other interesting elements to create different effects. Experiment with your flash in different positions. And try including the sun as a clear compositional element!

Allow your backgrounds to go dark or wash out completely. Use the midday sun to highlight details that you like. Use shadows to hide details that are distracting.

There are plenty of ways to level up your portraiture with high-contrast lighting. So experiment, have fun, and see what you can create!

12. Put your clients in the shade

Sure, you might be stuck photographing at midday…

…but you're not stuck directly in the sun, right? Instead of working in bright sunlight, look for a shaded area, then position your subject away from the harsh light.

You don't need much shade;足以覆盖您的客户。高楼、大树、高墙都可以完成这项工作！

为了获得最佳效果，请尝试将阴影光与大型反射器（自然或人造）结合起来。将拍摄对象放置在靠近反光板的位置，并用它来填充阴影，同时让阴影减少光线强度。

确保曝光的是客户的脸部而不是背景。这样，即使背景褪色，肤色也会看起来很好。

13.不要忘记编辑

现在我们来谈谈拍摄结束后如何处理刺眼的光线。严酷的阳光不会轻易原谅。它会突出每一个小瑕疵，并创造出可能远非讨人喜欢的强烈色彩——因此编辑尤为重要。

从修复基础开始。注意编辑软件中的高光和阴影恢复。恶劣的照明通常会导致高光过曝和阴影被剪裁。使用阴影和高光滑块来恢复一些丢失的细节。

那些令人难以抗拒的颜色呢？在阳光明媚的环境中，颜色可能会变得不自然地强烈，但借助编辑软件，您可以将它们调低。转到饱和度和鲜艳度滑块并进行调整，直到颜色看起来更自然。

最后的润色经常被忽视，但可以产生显着的效果。例如，我喜欢在肖像中添加小插图。这种技术巧妙地使图像的角落变暗，将观看者的注意力拉向拍摄对象。这是一个微小的变化，但增加了专业的感觉。

最后，不要低估新鲜眼睛的价值。完成编辑后，休息一下，然后重新查看图像。您经常会发现以前错过的细节或调整。 （根据我的经验，这个额外的步骤可以将你的肖像从优秀提升到令人惊叹！）

中午人像摄影技巧：最后的话

正午的光线当然不适合人像摄影，但您可以使用它来创作不同且有趣的照片。

当然，在柔和的光线下拍摄人像会更容易。但如果摄影很容易，那么每个人都会这样做。我分享的技巧和技巧不仅可以帮助您应对具有挑战性的照明，还可以帮助您应对挑战。他们让你利用它来创造独特的东西。请记住，每一个障碍都是伪装的机会。掌握这些技术可以让您在饱和的人像摄影世界中脱颖而出。

所以练习在强光下拍摄。带上反光板、闪光灯和稀松布。

让我们开始吧！

什么是平移摄影？

平移是一种在按下快门按钮时移动相机的技术。生成的照片具有美丽的条纹模糊：

左右平移是最常见的技术，但您也可以上下平移，甚至对角平移。请注意，平移图像通常具有移动的主体，例如汽车、骑自行车的人、慢跑者或奔跑的动物。这样，摄影师可以用相机跟踪拍摄对象的移动，虽然周围环境会变得模糊，但拍摄对象本身将保持清晰。

现在，并非所有相机移动都会产生创造性的平移效果 - 即使您确实设法捕捉到有趣的模糊，您的拍摄对象也可能不会变得清晰。为了获得最佳效果，您必须将仔细的技术与特定的相机设置结合起来，正如我稍后将在本文中讨论的那样。

什么时候应该使用平移？

平移是捕捉移动主体的艺术图像的好方法。这也是传达运动的绝佳方式，而且它看起来真的非常非常酷。因此，我鼓励您在遇到朝着可预测方向移动的相当快的物体时尝试一下，例如：

  • 汽车在路上疾驰
  • 野生动物在田野上竞速
  • 鸟儿在空中飞翔
  • 慢跑者跑过人行道

当光线变暗并且您很难以传统方式捕捉清晰的图像时，平移尤其方便。如果您在黄昏时拍摄飞行中的鸟类，您可能只能将快门速度提高到 1/80 秒，这会产生模糊的“标准”图像，但这是创建令人惊叹的平移拍摄的完美速度。合理？

现在，平移摄影确实会出现很多失误——即使您获得了经验——因此，如果您只对拍摄对象拍摄了一张照片（例如，一只稀有的鸟类碰巧飞过），通常最好捕捉一张正常的图像并离开又要再淘洗一天了。

而且由于平移会产生强烈的艺术图像，因此它并不总是适合新闻摄影（例如，当您为报纸拍摄足球比赛时）。

还有一件事：要捕捉出色的平移图像，拍摄对象应该靠近您的位置移动，而不是直接朝向或远离您。如果拍摄对象冲向您的相机，您将没有任何机会移动您的设置（即使用平移技术），并且您的拍摄对象将会变得模糊。

如何拍摄平移照片：设置和技巧

平移从移动的主体开始。当您第一次开始拍摄时，我建议您拍摄汽车；它们很容易找到，可以预测，而且运行速度相当快（因此您将有机会磨练平移速度）。随着时间的推移，您可以毕业到更困难的科目，例如运动员、野生动物和鸟类。

因此，找到一个有大量主题的地点，然后拨入您的设置。每种情况都是不同的 - 结果将取决于你的拍摄对象的速度 - 但以下是我的基本建议：

  • 拍照模式： 快门优先或手动
  • 快门速度：1/60秒
  • 光圈：f/8（尽管这是灵活的并且应该取决于曝光要求）
  • 感光度：100
  • 对焦模式：AF-C/AI-伺服或手动

一旦拍摄对象距离数百英尺，请通过取景器观察并用镜头跟踪其移动。不要等到它就在你身边。越早开始平移，您就越能测量拍摄对象的速度。

当拍摄对象接近您的位置时，射击几枪。 （您拍摄的图像越多，获得精彩图像的机会就越大！）并持续用镜头跟踪拍摄对象，即使它已移开。虽然看起来可能并非如此，但这种后续行动很重要。

最后，查看相机液晶显示屏上的图像。根据需要调整快门速度和曝光，然后重试！

平移摄影技巧和想法

现在您已经了解了平移摄影的基础知识，您已经准备好了解一些更高级的技巧、技术和想法了。

1. 为了获得最大的成功机会，请使用相机的连拍模式

连拍模式可让您在不到一秒的时间内拍摄多张照片，对于平移摄影来说非常方便。

正如我上面强调的，你拍摄的照片越多，你就越有可能捕捉到精彩的东西。因此，在开始平移之前，请将相机从单拍模式切换到连拍模式。 （如果您不确定如何执行此操作，请查看相机手册！）

然后，当需要拍摄时，按住快门按钮 - 并在平移时按住快门按钮，直到拍摄对象逐渐远离。您的相机将拍摄几张照片。您最终会得到大量文件需要分类，其中一些（如果幸运的话！）看起来不错。

除了增加获得良好效果的机会之外，相机的连拍模式还可以让您无需反复点击快门按钮，从而将相机抖动降至最低。

2.尝试不同的镜头

镜头的选择也会影响平底锅的外观。压缩视角的长焦镜头会比广角镜头产生更引人注目的效果，因此使用 70-200 毫米模型可能是一个很好的方法。 （另一方面，有时广角外观正是您想要的！）

请注意，这会产生实际后果；由于长焦压缩效应，广角镜头需要更长的快门速度才能产生与长焦相同的效果。

所以我的建议是尝试一下这两种类型的镜头，看看你的想法。从根本上讲，两者都不比另一个更好。这一切都取决于您想要创造什么！

3.尝试不同的快门速度

平移很大程度上取决于快门速度。如果快门速度太高，您最终会得到清晰的图像和零模糊效果。如果你的快门速度太低，你最终会得到一个脏兮兮、模糊的拍摄对象。

不幸的是，没有一种放之四海而皆准的方法来选择快门速度。虽然 1/60 秒是一个很好的起点，但较快的拍摄对象需要更快的快门速度，而较慢的拍摄对象需要较慢的快门速度。要获得漂亮的赛车平移镜头，您可能需要 1/125 秒的速度；为了让跑步者获得同样的效果，1/30s 是更好的选择。

因此，不断尝试很重要。每一系列拍摄后，请仔细查看液晶显示屏上的结果。如果您的拍摄对象看起来太清晰，请降低快门速度。如果您的拍摄对象看起来太模糊，请提高快门速度。

每当您取得成功时，请将快门与拍摄对象的组合牢记在心。这样，下次当你遇到类似的话题时，你就会知道该怎么做。

4. 将相机设置为快门优先模式

在上一节中，我提到平移时应该使用手动模式或快门优先模式。就我个人而言，我是快门优先的忠实粉丝。原因如下：

快门优先可让您在相机选择光圈时选择快门速度。换句话说，它可以让您专注于最重要的设置（快门速度），而其余的则由您的设备决定。

（您也可以选择 ISO，不过我通常建议将其设置为 100，然后忘记它，除非您处于非常黑暗的条件下。）

在可变照明条件下拍摄时，快门优先特别有用。如果您要拍摄在阴影中进出的汽车或骑自行车的人，快门优先将在保持快门速度恒定的同时处理曝光。

但如果您要使用手动模式，那么您需要不断调整光圈才能获得良好的曝光效果，并且在此过程中您可能会错过很多机会。

5.使用三脚架

绝对可以在手持时进行平移，有时会给您带来很好的效果。

但事情是这样的：

以低速快门手持拍摄可能会引起轻微的相机抖动，这会在照片中表现为不受欢迎的模糊。另外，当随着移动的拍摄对象平移相机时，您还可能通过上下身体运动引入抖动。

因此，为了确保您拍摄始终清晰的平移镜头，我鼓励您将相机安装在三脚架（或独脚架）上。

您需要仔细选择三脚架云台；某些云台专为平滑平移而设计，而其他云台会将您的相机向各个方向发送。

（与此相关的是，考虑一下您正在使用的镜头。某些镜头具有专门为平移设计的图像稳定功能。如果您有这样的图像稳定镜头，我强烈建议您测试一下！）

6. 准确对焦

平移时，您的拍摄对象将在场景中快速移动 - 因此快速准确地锁定焦点至关重要。

有两种方法可以使主体清晰对焦，同时背景呈现运动：

  1. 自动对焦技术：如果您刚刚开始进行平移摄影，或者无法预测拍摄对象与相机的距离，请使用自动对焦。为确保您准确对焦拍摄对象，请打开相机的连续对焦模式（尼康和索尼为 AF-C，佳能为 AI-Servo）。这将有助于您的相机在拍摄对象在画面上移动时持续对焦。当拍摄对象在远处时开始聚焦，然后在平移时将中心焦点对准拍摄对象的中心质量。
  2. 手动对焦技术：如果您确定拍摄对象将经过的距离（例如，您知道拍摄对象将沿着道路的特定车道行驶），那么我建议手动对焦。确定你的主题所在的位置，然后提前关注该点。您不必担心锁定和保持焦点 - 当您的拍摄对象经过时，只需平移相机即可拍摄一系列照片。

请记住：无论您选择哪种对焦方法，请始终将相机设置为连拍模式，并在拍摄对象移动时按住快门按钮！

7.正确定位自己

为了给镜头足够的对焦空间，请确保相机与移动主体之间保持一定的距离。

如果您距离拍摄对象太近，即使您使用上述手动对焦技术，镜头也可能难以（并且无法）对焦。

（为什么？所有镜头都有一个最小对焦距离；一旦拍摄对象移动到这个距离内，就无法对焦。）

另外，当拍摄对象又大又近时，很难将其保持在画面中。因此，请退后一两步，确保有足够的空间来拍摄精彩照片。

另外，当您选择位置时，请选择一个漂亮的背景。不要只是站在任何地方。相反，移动直到找到可以帮助您的主题脱颖而出的背景。

就我个人而言，我认为当主题与背景对比度良好并且至少有两种或更多背景颜色时，平移照片看起来很引人注目。然后背景提供上下文并帮助设置场景：

也就是说，您还可以创建具有统一背景（例如，绿树）的漂亮平移镜头。只要避免超繁忙的背景即可；你希望背景能够补充主题，而不是压倒主题。

8.添加flash

平移没有任何规则，虽然大多数摄影师使用自然光工作，但您可能还想尝试使用闪光灯。

现在，由于闪光速度极快（远远快于大多数相机提供的最大快门速度！），因此我们的目标是将单次闪光与平移技术结合起来，同时仍使用较慢的快门速度。

您需要将相机设置为慢速同步闪光模式，然后在按下快门按钮后仔细选择闪光灯何时闪光。您可以选择在拍摄开始或结束时闪光，从而产生截然不同的平移效果，所以我当然鼓励您进行尝试！

此外，这种慢速同步闪光技术只有在拍摄对象足够近并且闪光灯的功率足以产生影响时才有效，因此请确保您距离相当近（并在拍摄照片后在相机液晶显示屏上检查结果或两个）。

最后，如果您确实使用闪光灯，您将需要测试各种曝光设置以使其看起来正确。在某些情况下，您可能需要将闪光灯的强度降低一半或三分之一。

9.要有耐心和灵活性

如果您打算第一次尝试平移，您应该以实验的态度来对待它。这可能很有趣，但也可能非常令人沮丧。

如果您正在参加一个特殊活动，其中有快速移动的主题（例如赛车），您可能会想要混合您的摄影风格。不要只在整个照片拍摄中使用这种技术 - 确保您在使用快速快门速度时也拍摄一些更传统的照片。这样，您最终会得到各种各样的照片，即使您的平移图像效果不太好，您仍然会有一些好照片可以在社交媒体上与客户等分享。

另请记住，您的主要拍摄对象不太可能完全清晰且清晰。该技术的目的是获得与其背景相比相对清晰的主题。事实上，对主要拍摄对象进行一些模糊实际上会增加镜头中的运动感。

10.不要害怕在阳光明媚的日子里平移

正如您现在所知，平移涉及降低快门速度。

虽然这在光线不足的情况下很容易实现，但在阳光明媚的日子里，您可能很难在不导致曝光过度的情况下降低快门速度。

幸运的是，有几种方法可以解决这个问题。首先，将相机的 ISO 降低至 ISO 100，并确保光圈设置为极高的 f 值，例如 f/16。 （通常情况下，高 f 值会因衍射而导致模糊，但由于平移照片无论如何都会稍微模糊，所以这不会是问题！）

如果缩小光圈和降低 ISO 仍然无法提供足够慢的快门速度，请尝试在镜头前添加偏光滤镜或中性密度滤镜。它们会阻挡一些光线，让您以必要的快门速度捕捉详细的图像！

11.不要忘记构图

当您只考虑技术因素时，平移就足够困难了，但是一旦您了解了基础知识，注意构图也很重要。

您会看到，平移时，很容易只专注于与拍摄对象保持同步，以至于您最终只需将其放置在画面中央即可。虽然这可行，但有时最好将它们混合起来 - 也许将拍摄对象放置在框架边缘之一、框架顶部或底部等。

还有一个快速提示：使用相机中的构图辅助工具来帮助您。如果您的相机有网格对焦屏幕，请使用它。如果没有，请使用取景器中蚀刻的自动对焦点。考虑一下三分法，以及如何通过将拍摄对象放置在画面的三分之一位置而不是直接放在中间来给场景增添活力！
